<Summary source="https://sloganscopy.com/fafo-meaning-2026/">
# Summary of "FAFO Meaning 2026: What It Really Means, Where It Came From, and How People Use It Today"

**Source:** sloganscopy.com  
**Date:** January 21, 2026  
**Author:** Isla Penrose

## Key Facts and Information:

### Definition and Current Usage (2026)
- FAFO is an acronym that stands for "F*** Around and Find Out"
- It serves as a warning that someone's actions may lead to consequences
- The tone ranges from playful to serious depending on context
- In 2026, FAFO is described as "less shocking than before but still carries attitude"
- It is "no longer niche" and is "used globally"

### Origins and Evolution
- The phrase existed in spoken English for several decades before social media, particularly in military, street, and informal settings
- The acronym FAFO emerged later as internet culture embraced shortened expressions
- By the early 2020s, FAFO became mainstream slang
- The acronym "softened the phrase while keeping its impact"

### Platform Usage
- Widely used online in 2026, especially among younger users, creators, and meme culture fans
- Used across platforms like TikTok, Instagram, and WhatsApp
- Each platform shapes FAFO differently, but the core meaning remains consistent

### Search and Demographic Trends
- According to the article, Google Trends shows "steady interest, especially among users aged 18–35"
- The phrase "FAFO meaning 2026" is frequently searched by people encountering it in chats, memes, or social media

### Context and Appropriateness
- The article emphasizes that context matters more than the word itself in 2026
- Can be used jokingly among friends but is "usually" not safe for work environments unless very casual
- The same phrase can feel funny or aggressive depending on delivery

**Note:** This article appears to be an explainer/SEO-oriented piece about internet slang rather than news reporting, so it lacks traditional journalistic sourcing or polling data.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/19/us/donald-trump-memes-evolution-cec">
# Summary of CNN Article: "The Trump administration is all memes and ragebait"

**Source:** CNN  
**Date:** January 19, 2026  
**Author:** Leah Asmelash

## Key Facts and Observations:

### Timeline of Meme-Related Posts:
- **January 26, 2025:** Donald Trump shared an AI-generated portrait of himself dressed as a gangster with the letters "FAFO" behind him, one of a series of AI portraits posted throughout the year.
- **February 2025:** White House posted a fake Time magazine cover promoting Trump's efforts to cancel congestion pricing in Manhattan, with "TRUMP" replacing the Time banner and an AI-generated painting of Trump wearing a crown.
- **February 14, 2025:** A Valentine's poem was posted from the federal government.
- **May 2, 2025:** Trump reposted AI fan art of himself dressed as pope (between Pope Francis's death and the papal conclave).
- **May 4, 2025:** White House reposted an image of Trump as a muscular Jedi wielding a red lightsaber for "May the Fourth."
- **March 27, 2025:** White House posted AI-generated Studio Ghibli-style image of an ICE agent arresting a migrant.
- **July 2025:** White House posted an image of a sign reading "o Mg, di D t He WHi TE h Ou SE re ALLy Pos T t Hi S?" with text stating "Nowhere in the Constitution does it say we can't post banger memes."
- **November 2025:** White House posted an image with its location listed as "Rent Free in Democrats' Heads" in response to X's account-geolocation feature.

### Expert Analysis (Named Sources):

**Audrey Halversen** (political communication scholar, University of Michigan): "He is not just latching onto things his base supports, but latching on to things that he knows will anger the other side. Which then, of course, makes these posts gain a lot of attention."

**Dannagal Young** (director of the Center for Political Communication, University of Delaware): "The entire ethos and aesthetic of this administration is spectacle and subversion of norms. You don't do that through deliberation or argument, but through symbols."

**Shannon McGregor** (professor at University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, focused on social media and political communication): "This is what happens when online reply guys get in the White House."

### Official Statement:

**Abigail Jackson** (White House spokeswoman): "The success of the White House's social media pages speak for itself. Through engaging posts and banger memes, we are successfully communicating the President's extremely popular agenda and forcing his Democrat critics to take indefensible positions. There's a reason so many people try to copy our style – our message resonates."

### Context on "FAFO":
The article specifically mentions that in January 2025, Trump posted AI-generated pictures of himself as a 1920s-esque gangster with the acronym "FAFO" behind him, posted shortly after he "strong-armed Colombia into taking deported migrants."

### General Observations:
- The article describes a "deliberately transgressive, meme-heavy style of communication" as the defining characteristic of Trump administration communications during his second term's first year.
- Meme posting expanded beyond Trump's personal accounts to federal agencies including Department of Education, Border Patrol, and Department of Defense.
- The administration utilized generative AI tools for mass production of images and video.
- Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) was mentioned as embodying the "tryhard, combative internet posting spirit," though Musk stepped down after five months.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/us/wall-street-loves-the-laughs-trump-acronym-parodies-like-taco-and-fafo-take-meme-markets-by-storm/articleshow/121540432.cms">
# Summary of Article: "Wall Street loves the laughs: Trump acronym parodies like TACO and FAFO take meme markets by storm"

**Source:** The Economic Times

## Key Facts and Information:

### Context:
- During President Donald Trump's second term, traders are creating meme-worthy acronyms based on his slogan-heavy style
- These acronyms have been circulating among trading desks for the past four months of Trump's second term
- While often humorous, these memes reflect serious investor concerns about changing policies and economic risks

### FAFO Specifically:
- **Definition:** FAFO stands for "Fuck Around and Find Out"
- **Origin:** The acronym was coined long before Trump was elected president
- **Current Usage:** It is becoming "more and more common in trading desk discourse"
- **Purpose:** It is employed to record the chaos and volatility of the financial markets brought about by Trump's policymaking process

### Other Related Acronyms (for context):
- **TACO** (Trump Always Chickens Out) - characterizes Trump's inconsistency on tariffs
- **MEGA** (Make Europe Great Again) - refers to surge in European market interest
- **YOLO** (You Only Live Once) - encourages outsized risks in concentrated investment themes

### Expert Opinion:
- **Mark Spindel**, Chief Investment Officer at Potomac River Capital LLC: stated the market is stuck in a "pinball machine as a result of Trump's policymaking process"
- **Art Hogan**, strategist at B. Riley Wealth: discussed YOLO's connection to high-momentum strategies post-election

### White House Response:
- White House spokesperson Kush Desai said these acronyms demonstrate how analysts have ridiculed President Trump and his agenda

**Note:** This article discusses the increasing popularity of "FAFO" in trading desk discourse during Trump's second term, which could be relevant for understanding potential changes in Google Trends interest for this term during the forecast period.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/global-trends/us-news-us-colombia-standoff-after-fafo-bamf-goes-viral-over-trump-colombia-diplomatic-standoff-triggered-by-migrants-issue-elon-musk-mother-what-does-it-mean/articleshow/117608595.cms">
# Summary of Article: "After FAFO, BAMF goes viral over Trump-Colombia diplomatic standoff triggered by migrants' issue. What does it mean?"

**Source:** The Economic Times

## Key Facts and Events:

1. **Diplomatic Standoff Context:** Colombia initially refused to accept US military planes carrying approximately 80 deported Colombian migrants, which triggered a diplomatic crisis between the US and Colombia.

2. **Trump's Response and Tariff Threats:**
   - Trump announced punitive measures including tariffs starting at 25% on all Colombian imports, with potential increase to 50%
   - Announced visa restrictions for all party members in Colombia, their family members, and supporters
   - Announced enhanced customs and border protection inspections of Colombian nationals and cargo
   - Threatened IEEPA Treasury, Banking and Financial Sanctions

3. **Colombia's Initial Response:** Colombia threatened to impose similar retaliatory tariffs on US imports.

4. **Resolution:** According to White House press secretary Karolina Leavitt, "The Government of Colombia has agreed to all of President Trump's terms, including the unrestricted acceptance of all illegal aliens from Colombia returned from the United States, including on US military aircraft, without limitation or delay."

## Viral Acronyms:

1. **FAFO:** Stands for "F— around and find out" - Trump used this acronym in a Truth Social post featuring a vintage gangster-style image criticizing Colombian President Gustavo Petro
   
2. **BAMF:** Stands for "bada** motherf**ker" - Elon Musk used this term after Colombia agreed to Trump's terms

## Background on FAFO Term:

- According to Financial Express (as cited in the article), FAFO signifies that actions have consequences
- Gained mainstream traction through memes and internet culture in the late 2010s
- According to Urban Dictionary, earliest mentions linked to biker terminology
- The Washington Post traced its origin to African American Vernacular English (AAVE)
- Donald Trump Jr. also used the term in relation to the 2020 election and Democrats
</Summary>

**You've got until May to migrate your Fitbit data, or you'll lose it for good**
Google has extended the deadline for Fitbit users to migrate their standalone Fitbit accounts to a Google account to May 19, 2026, following prior extensions from an original 2025 deadline and a February 2026 cutoff. After this date, users who have not migrated will lose access to their Fitbit accounts entirely. Google has also introduced a grace period: users may download or delete their Fitbit data—including activity history, health metrics, and long-term trends—until July 15, 2026, after which data deletion will begin. The extension indicates Google's ongoing effort to transition users without abrupt enforcement. The company has confirmed that access to Fitbit-only accounts will be cut off regardless of device usage. The original plan to discontinue standalone Fitbit accounts remains unchanged, with a Google account now required to continue using Fitbit services. Users are advised not to ignore the deadline, as missing it will result in permanent loss of account and data.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 02, 2026 11:00 AM
Source:[Trusted Reviews](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/youve-got-until-may-to-migrate-your-fitbit-data-or-youll-lose-it-for-good)

**Realty Income Stock: Integration Under Scrutiny Ahead of Key 2025 Results**
Realty Income is approaching a critical test following its acquisition of Spirit Realty Capital, with the market closely monitoring the integration of new retail and industrial properties. The company is set to release its Q4 2025 and full-year 2025 financial results on February 24, 2026, after the U.S. market close. This report will serve as a key indicator of whether the expanded portfolio delivers the promised operational stability and diversification. Investors are assessing the efficiency of the integration process, particularly whether the AFFO (Adjusted Funds From Operations) contribution from Spirit Realty Capital’s assets meets expectations. The broader outlook remains challenging due to the sensitivity of the triple-net lease real estate sector to interest rate movements—rising or sustained high financing costs could hinder the company’s acquisition-driven growth strategy. Additionally, operational performance in retail and industrial sectors is under scrutiny, as shifts in consumer behavior or declining industrial demand could negatively impact lease renewals and property valuations. The February 24, 2026, release is expected to clarify these trends and shape market expectations for the remainder of the fiscal year. According to a February 1, 2026, analysis by Aktien Check, Spirit Realty Capital’s latest financials indicate urgent action is needed for shareholders, raising questions about whether to buy or sell the stock.
Original language: de
Publish date: February 01, 2026 05:35 PM
Source:[Aktien Check](https://www.aktiencheck.de/news/Artikel-Realty_Income_Aktie_Integration_Fokus-19424927)

**Energy, Savings, and Fees: What Changes on February 1**
Starting Sunday, February 1, 2026, several new pricing changes take effect in France affecting energy, banking, and savings. Electricity bills are expected to slightly decrease due to a reduction in one of the taxes included in all subscriptions, resulting in an estimated annual saving of 10 euros per household. Similarly, gas bills will also drop as global prices decline. However, savings products face a setback: the interest rate on the Livret A, the most popular savings account in France, will fall from 1.7% to 1.5%, and the Livret d'Épargne Populaire (LEP) rate will drop from 2.7% to 2.5%, both due to declining inflation. This has led some, like Loïc, a commercial manager, to shift toward riskier investments such as cryptocurrency and real estate projects, stating he no longer relies on the Livret A for reliable returns. Meanwhile, banking fees are increasing by an average of 3%, a trend noted by Renaud, who finds the cost excessive and unjustified, especially without corresponding improvements in services. Finally, toll prices across France will rise by an average of 0.86%, the smallest increase since 2021.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 01, 2026 12:46 PM
Source:[Franceinfo](https://www.franceinfo.fr/economie/livrets-gaz-electricite-ce-qui-change-au-1er-fevrier_7778156.html)

**What Changes Await French Citizens Starting February 1, 2026?**
The podcast hosted by Maxime Lledo and Philippe Crevel discusses key changes expected to take effect for French citizens starting February 1, 2026. The primary financial change involves a reduction in the interest rate on the Livret A from 1.7% to 1.5%, driven by an inflation rate of 0.9% in 2025 and prevailing interest rate trends. The hosts emphasize the need for French savers to diversify their investments, highlighting life insurance (assurance-vie) with euro funds offering around 2.7% capital guarantees. Additionally, electricity bills will decrease by 9 € annually due to the removal of a tax funding energy sector retirements. Gas bills are also expected to drop, linked to global gas price declines. Meanwhile, toll fees will rise by 0.5% to 1% depending on the concession, but at a slower pace than previously observed.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 01, 2026 07:05 AM
Source:[Sud Radio](https://www.sudradio.fr/emission/sud-radio-vous-explique-1034)

**Is the patent office becoming more patent-friendly?**
The U.S. patent system has shown a measurable shift toward being more favorable to patent owners, particularly in post-grant proceedings such as inter partes review (IPR) and post-grant review (PGR), which are administered by the Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB) at the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO). From 2011 to 2024, IPR institution rates remained stable in the mid-60% range, peaking at approximately 68% in fiscal year 2024. Historically, once instituted, IPR and PGR proceedings resulted in the invalidation of 65–75% of challenged claims, leading to the PTAB being labeled a 'patent death squad.' However, a significant policy shift began on March 26, 2025, when the USPTO formalized discretionary denials—decisions not to institute proceedings even when statutory thresholds are met. From January 21 to March 23, 2025, 31% of denials were discretionary, but this rose to 59% from March 26 to April 30, 2025, and to 77% from May 1 to July 1, 2025. By September 2025, institution rates had declined to approximately 35% due to increased discretionary denials. In January 2026, the USPTO designated several PTAB decisions on discretionary denial as precedential and informative, establishing binding guidance on factors such as parallel district court litigation timing (under the Fintiv framework), serial petitions, and procedural compliance, including real-party-in-interest disclosure. These changes have shifted leverage toward patent owners at the institution stage, although the PTAB remains a high-risk forum for challenged claims. The trend indicates a strategic effort to reduce the number of proceedings initiated while maintaining rigorous scrutiny on those that proceed.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2026 06:00 AM
Source:[Business Journal](https://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2026/02/01/patent-office-more-friendly.html)

**The Safe-Haven Value Falters Amid Geopolitical Shifts and Economic Rebalancing**
Households are seeking alternatives to maximize their savings amid significant geopolitical shifts. Traditional safe-haven assets, which had reached historic highs, are showing signs of instability as uncertainty around the U.S. presidency and the Federal Reserve's direction subsides. Kevin Warsh, Donald Trump’s chosen successor to Jerome Powell as Fed chair, helped stabilize the U.S. dollar with a more technical profile, leading to a rebound in the dollar and a decline in traditional safe-haven assets like gold and silver. Bitcoin continues its downward trend, failing to prove its status as a refuge asset. Meanwhile, improved liquidity expectations have driven the Euribor lower, ending a five-month streak of increases since the European Central Bank (ECB) maintained interest rates near 2%. This offers a slight relief for mortgage holders and those seeking affordable financing, with inflation under control and no immediate signs of rate changes—though the ECB’s upcoming meeting will determine the next move. In Spain, the economy grew by 2.8% in 2025, though momentum is slowing compared to 2024, with household consumption and investment remaining key drivers. E-commerce has become a standard channel for purchases and services, but consumer complaints are rising—particularly over delayed refunds, long wait times for size exchanges, and defective products. The Spanish Congress rejected the decree for pension increases in 2026, leaving the government to maneuver to secure a 2.7% revaluation in February’s pension payments to protect the purchasing power of over nine million pensioners. Despite fears that AI may displace qualified workers, U.S. data shows that professions most exposed to AI are still growing strongly.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 01, 2026 05:34 AM
Source:[LaVanguardia](https://www.lavanguardia.com/dinero/bolsillo/20260201/11454515/mercados-valores-refugio-trump.html)

**Fitbit extends Google Account deadline to May 2026, with data deleted shortly after**
Google has extended the deadline for Fitbit users to transition from standalone Fitbit accounts to Google Accounts to May 19, 2026, up from the previous date of February 2, 2026. After this date, users will no longer be able to access their Fitbit accounts unless they migrate to a Google Account. The migration process is quick and results in no data loss. Existing Fitbit account holders can still download their data anytime before July 15, 2026, after which the data will be permanently deleted. Google has required new users to sign in with a Google Account for some time, but the updated deadline provides more time for existing users to make the switch. According to 9to5Google, this change allows users to retain access to their Fitbit data until July 15, 2026, while enforcing full reliance on Google Accounts after May 19, 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2026 04:30 PM
Source:[9to5Google](https://9to5google.com/2026/01/31/fitbit-google-account-may-2026-deadline/)

**What Changes on February 1, 2026: Livret A, Electricity, Tolls, Cigarettes, and More**
Starting February 1, 2026, several changes will impact household budgets in France. The interest rate on the Livret A will decrease from 1.7% to 1.5%, while the Livret d'Épargne Populaire (LEP) rate will drop to 2.5% from 2.7%. The electricity subscription fee will fall by approximately €10 annually due to a reduction in the tariff contribution for transmission (CTA) from 21.93% to 15%. Highway tolls will increase by an average of 0.86%, though this is below the inflation rate (0.9% from October 2024 to October 2025). Cigarette prices will rise for certain brands: British American Tobacco products (Lucky Strike, Dunhill, Vogue, Winfield) will increase by €0.20, Gauloises and News by €0.40, reaching €13 per pack of 20. Conversely, some Winston and Camel packs will decrease by €0.10. Bank fees will rise on average by 3%, with account maintenance fees increasing to €24.64 annually (over 6% rise) and card fees rising by 2%. Voter registration for the 2026 municipal elections (March 15 and 22) must be completed by February 4 online or February 6 in person. The energy check (chèque énergie) application window for eligible but unregistered households closes on February 28. From February 7, individuals must first contact the Tourism and Travel Mediator before pursuing legal action for compensation. Paper restaurant vouchers (Tickets Restaurants) will no longer be valid as of February 1, while digital vouchers remain valid until the end of the month; employers may extend their validity until March 15 upon request.
Original language: fr
Publish date: January 30, 2026 04:29 PM
Source:[lanouvellerepublique.fr](https://www.lanouvellerepublique.fr/a-la-une/livrets-a-tarif-de-l-electricite-prix-des-peages-cigarettes-ce-qui-change-a-partir-du-1er-fevrier-1769790577)

**"FAFO" Narrative Drives the Markets in 2026**
In early 2026, financial markets exhibited bullish momentum in gold and stock indices, while cryptocurrencies faced a selloff, signaling reduced investor interest. The 'buy America' narrative gained traction, driving the US dollar higher and boosting stock indices—particularly the DAX, which rose due to increased military spending and strong performance in defensive stocks like Rheinmetall, which surged over 20% in 2026 and approximately 150% from 2025. Geopolitical tensions escalated with the US seizing Venezuelan President Maduro and a Russian oil tanker, fueling demand for defensive assets such as gold, silver, the Swiss franc, and Japanese yen (despite yen depreciation from carry trade activity despite rising 30-year bond yields). This shift is attributed to a 'FAFO' narrative—President Trump’s intervention in the oil market and disruption of global geopolitical stability. The January 13, 2026, Non-Farm Payrolls (NFP) report showed a 50,000 job increase, below the projected 70,000, initially pressuring the US dollar, but it recovered to close the day in the green. Gold fluctuated but ended the day positive.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 13, 2026 09:21 AM
Source:[FXEmpire.com](https://www.fxempire.com/forecasts/article/fafo-narrative-drives-the-markets-in-2026-1572468)

**“FAFO” narrative drives the markets in 2026 - FinanceFeeds**
In early January 2026, financial markets showed bullish momentum in gold and stock indices, particularly the DAX, driven by a resurgence of the 'buy America' narrative and rising geopolitical tensions involving the U.S. and Venezuela, including the seizure of President Maduro and a Russian oil tanker. Defensive stocks such as Rheinmetall rose over 20% in 2026 and nearly 150% since 2025, while Lockheed Martin (LMT) gained 4.5% on Friday. This shift has fueled demand for safe-haven assets like gold, silver, the Swiss franc, and Japanese yen—though the yen was pressured by carry trade activity despite rising 30-year U.S. bond yields. The term 'FAFO' (Foreign Affairs, Foreign Oil) has emerged to describe President Trump’s intervention in the oil market and its destabilizing effect on global geopolitics. The U.S. Non-Farm Payrolls (NFP) report on Friday showed a 50k increase, below the anticipated 70k, initially pressuring the dollar, but it closed the day in green. Gold also closed positively despite wobbling. Despite the weaker NFP, traders do not expect rate cuts at the upcoming FOMC meetings in January or March, with odds of rate stability increasing according to the FedWatch Tool. U.S. 30-year bond yields declined slightly, providing limited support for the dollar. The next key event is the U.S. CPI report on Tuesday, expected to show cooling inflation, though already priced in. Gold (XAUUSD) is in a strong seasonal uptrend window, having bounced off the 20-day moving average—a key dynamic support—indicating bullish momentum with no overbought signals, as it remains below prior all-time highs and the Bollinger Band upper band. The S&P 500 has lagged behind the DAX, with tech stocks underperforming compared to financial and industrial sectors. However, defensive and energy stocks are regaining strength post-escalation. Earnings from major financial firms like JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and BlackRock starting January 12 may influence market direction. The S&P 500 is expected to open flat, with potential acceleration later in the week as more data—especially CPI and corporate earnings—becomes available.

**Council of Federation Approves Law to Increase Maximum Microloan Amount for Legal Entities**
The Russian Council of Federation approved a law on December 19, 2025, increasing the maximum microloan amount for legal entities and individual entrepreneurs from 5 million to 15 million rubles, effective April 1, 2026. The law also introduces stricter requirements for microfinance organizations (MFOs). The initiative was proposed by senators Anatoly Artamonov, Mukhambiy Ulbashev, Alexander Shenderyuk-Zhidkov, Vladimir Dzhabarov, Galina Karelova, and deputies of the State Duma. The change aims to modernize the outdated 2018 limit, expand access to financing for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), develop the domestic capital market, and meet market demand. Additionally, the law reduces the maximum interest rate on loans up to one year from 130% to 100% starting April 1, 2026. A transition period begins October 2026, during which MFOs cannot issue more than two loans to a client with a total cost exceeding 200% annually. From April 1, 2027, MFOs will be prohibited from issuing more than one loan to an individual with a total cost above 100% annually. Starting January 1, 2027, MFOs may not enter into new consumer loan agreements with individuals until four days after fully repaying a previous loan or credit with a total cost exceeding 100%. The Bank of Russia’s board may adjust this threshold in case of significant market changes. Furthermore, MFOs are banned from restructuring consumer loan obligations via novation or adding unpaid interest, penalties, or other fees to the principal debt. These measures aim to protect borrowers and regulate the MFO sector.

**CBRF Expects Continued Decline in MFO Market Profits in 2026 Amid Regulatory Reforms**
The Central Bank of Russia (CBRF) expects the trend of declining net profit for microfinance organizations (MFOs) to continue in 2026, according to Nikita Akimov, Deputy Director of the Department of Non-Bank Lending at the CBRF. He cited three upcoming reforms as key drivers: socialization measures (reducing interest rates and the number of loans held by individuals), the introduction of a Unified Biometric System (EBS), and the implementation of official income verification for calculating macroprudential limits. Akimov noted that companies already preparing for the official income requirement are experiencing reduced profitability due to significant investments in technology and operations. He stated that this trend is likely to persist into 2026, although no specific profit percentage forecast was provided. Data from the first nine months of 2025 already show a slight cooling in the MFO market, attributed to POS loan regulations and macroprudential limits on auto-loans. In the first half of 2025, MFO profits declined by 5% year-on-year, with more than half of companies reporting reduced net profit compared to the same period in 2024, totaling 25 billion rubles. A draft law, effective from July 1, 2026, to January 1, 2027, will prohibit MFOs from issuing loans with a total cost exceeding 200% annually to clients with two or more outstanding loans above 200% annually. From January 1, 2027, MFOs will be barred from issuing loans with a total cost above 100% annually to clients with existing debts above 100% annually, with a mandatory three-day waiting period after debt repayment before a new loan can be issued. The CBRF retains the authority to adjust the cost-of-credit cap under significant market changes. Additionally, the maximum total cost of consumer loans and short-term loans (up to one year) will be reduced from 130% to 100% annually.

**State Duma Approves Stricter Rules for Microloans**
The State Duma has approved in first reading a new law that will tighten regulations on microloans from non-bank financial organizations (MFOs). Starting July 1, 2026, individuals will be limited to no more than two high-interest loans (over 200% annual interest). From January 1, 2027, only one such loan with interest above 100% annually will be allowed. A new rule requires a four-day waiting period after repaying a loan before taking out a new one. The maximum loan overpayment will be reduced from 130% to 100% annually. The law aims to prevent people from falling into debt traps, as many borrowers take new loans to repay old ones, leading to spiraling debt. The proposed changes are intended to break this cycle. Additionally, the maximum microloan amount for entrepreneurs will increase from 5 million ₽ to 15 million ₽, to improve access to financing for small businesses. The regulator suggests slightly adjusting the implementation timeline: the two-high-interest-loan limit will take effect on September 1, 2026; the one-loan rule and the four-day waiting period will begin on March 1, 2027; and the increased loan limit for businesses will start on March 1, 2026. The law is being promoted as a measure to protect consumers while supporting small business development.

**Online search interest in advisors sets record, reveals investor fear**
Google Trends data shows a sharp rise in online search interest for financial advisors, peaking at 62 in the weeks before President Trump’s tariff announcement and reaching a new record in August 2025. The trend reflects investors’ growing concern amid market volatility, with a 2022 SmartAsset study indicating that over half of advisors cited stock‑market volatility as the main reason clients sought advice. Associate director Andrew Blake of Cerulli Associates notes that “everything sort of seems to be in chaos when it comes to rates and trade,” and that this confusion drives investors to seek professional guidance. Data from the American Association of Individual Investors (AAII) and the Financial Advisor Confidence Outlook (FACO) show that individual investors’ bearish sentiment tracks closely with advisor search interest, whereas advisors’ outlooks are less correlated. The VIX index, measuring expected near‑term volatility, correlates moderately with advisor search interest, sitting between retail sentiment and advisor views. Filip Telibasa, owner of Benzina Wealth, explains that conflicting opinions on social media fuel uncertainty for retail investors, prompting more to contact advisors. Telibasa’s own experience illustrates how improving online presence—adding a direct calendar link and reducing friction—can convert search interest into booked meetings, with his appointment volume growing from near zero to one or two per week. The article suggests that advisors who effectively position themselves online can capitalize on the heightened demand for professional financial guidance.
